noun.description: The internal organ in which the major part of the digestion of food occurs, being (in humans and many mammals) a pear-shaped enlargement of the alimentary canal linking the esophagus to the small intestine.
An appetite for food or drink.
examples: she doesn't have the stomach to eat anything

verb.description: Consume (food or drink) without feeling or being sick.
examples: if you cannot stomach orange juice, try apple juice

phrases: Napoleon recognised that an army marches on its stomach but, today, a more pertinent question for all farmers and tax payers is: Should British soldiers be stuffing themselves with foreign meat in their rations?
If an army marches on its stomach, software product development at every large corporation marches on the Zee cabinet.
Emperor Napoleon had said an army marches on its stomach.
As Napoleon once said, an army marches on its stomach - hence the importance of getting tucker to the troops.
Napoleon said that an army marches on its stomach, and I fed these guys, says the Fannie Mae leader who spearheaded the move last summer.
origin: Middle English: from Old French estomac, stomaque, via Latin from Greek stomakhos gullet, from stoma mouth. The early sense of the verb was be offended at, resent (early 16th century).
